pull.title: rpc: add optional peer_ids param to filter getpeerinfo
pull.body:
Adds an optional `peer_ids` parameter to `getpeerinfo` to filter results by peer IDs.

This is useful when using bitcoin-cli or the console to inspect specific peers referenced in debug.log.

rename.from: rpc: add optional nodeid param to filter getpeerinfo
rename.to: rpc: add optional peer_id param to filter getpeerinfo

rename.from: rpc: add optional peer_id param to filter getpeerinfo
rename.to: rpc: add optional peer_ids param to filter getpeerinfo

events.body: Updated to use `peer_ids` (array) instead of a single `peer_id`. This allows filtering by multiple peers in one call and aligns better with RPC design. Functional tests adjusted.
I would do peer_id|peer_ids and accept both a single number (most common use) or an array (efficient).

> I would do peer_id|peer_ids and accept both a single number (most common use) or an array (efficient).

I don't think `RPCArg` currently supports a single argument that can be either a num or an array (Maybe  RPCArg::Type::ANY?). One option would be to add two separate optional arguments: one for a single ID and another for the list, then merge both into the filter set internally. That would allow `getpeerinfo 7` for convenience and `getpeerinfo -1 '[1,3,4,7]'` for multiple.

---

Figured it out in the latest push, skipped type checking for peer_ids

> I would do peer_id|peer_ids and accept both a single number (most common use) or an array (efficient).

Skipped type checking and added simple cases so `getpeerinfo 7` and `getpeerinfo '[1,2,3]'` should work

<!--85328a0da195eb286784d51f73fa0af9-->

events.message: rpc: add optional "peer_ids" filter to getpeerinfo with test coverage

comments.body: this should be optional, not a magic default value
Also, you can use the `self.Arg` to get the value.
Updated to use Optional::OMITTED to avoid relying on magic default value. Thanks!
Squashed commits. Renamed to filter_id. Evaluating how to best use self.Arg with NodeId. Will follow up

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -178,6 +178,19 @@ def test_getpeerinfo(self):
                 "version": 0,
             },
         )
+
+        self.log.info("Check getpeerinfo with nodeid filter")
+        all_peers = self.nodes[0].getpeerinfo()
+        for peer in all_peers:
+            filtered = self.nodes[0].getpeerinfo(peer["id"])
+            assert_equal(len(filtered), 1)
+            assert_equal(filtered[0]["id"], peer["id"])
+            self.log.debug("Filtered peer id {}: OK".format(peer["id"]))
+
+        self.log.info("Check getpeerinfo with nonexistent nodeid filter")
+        nonexistent_id = max(p["id"] for p in all_peers) + 1000
+        assert_equal(self.nodes[0].getpeerinfo(nonexistent_id), [])
comments.body:
Would it make sense to throw a `JSONRPCError(RPC_MISC_ERROR,"Peer does not exist")` if the peer does not exist, Similar to the [getblockfrompeer](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/rpc/blockchain.cpp#L521-L523) instead of sending back an empty array?

where error is thrown in [PeerManagerImpl::FetchBlock](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/net_processing.cpp#L1880)

comments.body: I'd lean toward keeping this behavior for consistency unless there's a broader plan to split these use cases into distinct RPCs (say: `getpeerbyid`). The name `getpeerinfo` is arguably a bit misleading since it returns a list of peers, but given that it's established, returning an empty array when filtering seems appropriate to me.

comments.body: If others think we should return an empty array then sounds good to me!
Only need to check `opt_peer_id` here, since we'd never get here if it's set to something different
Since we have to iterate peers to find the right one, maybe this should be a list (unordered_set in C++)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -122,7 +122,9 @@ static RPCHelpMan getpeerinfo()
     return RPCHelpMan{
         "getpeerinfo",
         "Returns data about each connected network peer as a json array of objects.",
comments.body:
Can mention in the RPC help.

```diff
- "Returns data about each connected network peer as a json array of objects.",
+ "Returns data about each connected network peer as a json array of objects.\n"
+ "Optionally filter by peer index.\n",

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -122,7 +122,9 @@ static RPCHelpMan getpeerinfo()
     return RPCHelpMan{
         "getpeerinfo",
         "Returns data about each connected network peer as a json array of objects.",
comments.body: Added line to help text, preferred using peer id naming instead of index, to avoid confusion with the array index
First condition checks if the parameter is defined so it returns all results even if peer_id is 0

> Since we have to iterate peers to find the right one, maybe this should be a list (unordered_set in C++)

I agree, the last push swapped to an unordered_set with an array argument
RPCArg doesn't support '|' in names and will throw a rpc error when it gets called. https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/73220fc0f958f9b65f66cf0cf042af220b312fc6/src/rpc/util.cpp#L923
